caution.para: The ruleset shown in this article uses Shorewall features that are not available in Shorewall versions prior to 4.6.11

section.title: Introduction
section.para: The configuration described in this article represents the network at shorewall.org during the summer of 2015. It uses the following Shorewall features:

listitem.para: A DMZ with three "systems" using Proxy ARP and running in Linux Containers (LXC)

section.para: Linux runs the firewall and the servers (although they run in LXC containers on the firewall system). Linux is not used natively on any of our other systems.. I rather run Windows natively (Windows 7 Professional) and run Linux in VMs under VirtualBox. This approach has a number of advantages:

listitem.para: The virtual disks used by Linux are just files in the NTFS file system. There is no need to pre-allocate one or more partitions for use by Linux. Some large applications, like Google Earth, are installed only on Windows.
The Linux VMs emulate standard hardware that is well-supported by Linux.
All DRM-protected media can be handled under Windows.

section.para: VirtualBox is fast (when your processor supports virtualization extensions) and very easy to use. I highly recommend it!

section.title: Network Topology
section.para: Our network is diagrammed in the following graphic.
We have two accounts with Comcast:

listitem.para: This is a high-speed (40mb/8mb) link with a single dynamic IPv4 address. We are not allowed to run servers accessible through this account.
Comcast Business Class Service with a /29 (70.90.191.120/29).

section.para: The wired local network is restricted to my home office. The wireless network is managed by a wireless router which we use only as an access point -- its WAN interface is unused and it is configured to not do NAT. The wireless network uses WPA2 personal security.

section.title: Shorewall Configuration
section.para: This section contains excerpts from the Shorewall configuration.

section.title: /etc/shorewall/mirrors
section.para: Defines the IP addresses of the Shorewall mirror sites.

section.title: /etc/shorewall/params
section.para:
INCLUDE mirrors
LOG="NFLOG(0,0,1)"
INT_IF=eth0 TUN_IF=tun+ COMB_IF=eth2 COMC_IF=eth1
MYNET=70.90.191.120/29 #External IP addresses handled by this router DMZ_NET=70.90.191.124/31 FW_NET=70.90.191.120/30 INT_NET=172.20.1.0/24 DYN_NET=$(find_first_interface_address_if_any $COMC_IF) SMC_ADDR=10.1.10.11
[ -n "${DYN_NET:=67.170.122.219}" ]
DYN_NET=${DYN_NET}/32
DMZ=fw:$DMZ_NET
LISTS=:70.90.191.124 SERVER=:70.90.191.125 MAIL=172.20.1.200
PROXY=Yes STATISTICAL=Yes SQUID2=Yes
[ -n "${EXPERIMENTAL:=0}" ] As shown, this file defines variables to hold the various lists of IP addresses that I need to maintain. To simplify network reconfiguration, I also use variables to define the log level and the network interfaces.

section.para: if [ -f /var/lib/dhcpcd/dhcpcd-eth1.info ]; then . /var/lib/dhcpcd/dhcpcd-eth1.info echo $GATEWAY fi The Comcast line has a dynamic IP address assigned with the help of dhclient.

section.title: /etc/shorewall/isusable
section.para:
local status status=0
[ -f /etc/shorewall/${1}.status ] && status=$(cat /etc/shorewall/${1}.status)
return $statusFor use with lsm.

section.title: /etc/shorewall/restored
section.para:
if [ -z "$(ps ax | grep 'lsm ' | grep -v 'grep ' )" ]; then start_lsm fi
chmod 744 ${VARDIR}/stateIf lsm isn't running then start it. Make the state file world-readable.

section.para: #SOURCE DEST PROVIDER PRIORITY 70.90.191.121,\ 70.90.191.123 - ComcastB 1000 &COMC_IF - ComcastC 1000 br0 - ComcastB 11000 172.20.1.191 - ComcastB 1000These entries simply ensure that outgoing traffic uses the correct interface.

section.title: /etc/shorewall/stoppedrules
section.para: #TARGET HOST(S) DEST PROTO DEST SOURCE # PORT(S) PORT(S) ACCEPT INT_IF:172.20.1.0/24 $FW NOTRACK COMB_IF - 41 NOTRACK $FW COMB_IF 41 ACCEPT COMB_IF $FW 41 ACCEPT COMC_IF $FW udp 67:68Keep the lights on while Shorewall is stopped.

section.title: /etc/shorewall/started
section.para: if [ "$COMMAND" = start -o -z "$(ps ax | grep 'lsm ' | grep -v 'grep ' )" ]; then start_lsm fi If lsm isn't running then start it.

section.title: /etc/shorewall/stopped
section.para:
if [ "$COMMAND" = stop -o "$COMMAND" = clear ]; then killall lsm 2> /dev/null fi
chmod 744 ${VARDIR}/stateKill lsm if the command is stop or clear. Make the state file world-readable.
